The study concludes that “millions of Americans have contracted COVID-19 unnecessarily and hundreds of thousands of deaths could have been prevented.” In total, the report found that one-third of COVID-19 deaths and around 40 percent of infections were linked to a lack of health insurance.

The report singles out employer-based health care, hospitals focusing on profits over safety, understaffing at nursing homes, and underfunding of public health infrastructure. It notes that existing disparities exacerbated the impact of the pandemic in Black communities in particular.
“The cardinal sin of our health care system is that it puts profits over people and corporations over communities,” the report reads.

Ultimately, the report recommends a Medicare-for-All system, pointing out that it “would be better able to disburse funds in emergency situations and to purchase necessary supplies, such as PPE or testing materials, and machinery, such as ventilators or respirators, during a crisis and get them where they need to go in a timely manner.”

• NEW WARNINGS ABOUT DANGERS OF REOPENING SCHOOLS:

published by the Institute for New Economic Thinking warns that the CDC’s guidelines for reopening schools may be insufficient to prevent COVID outbreaks similar to those seen in the U.K. The paper notes that children were between two and seven times more likely to be the first case in their household compared to adults. The report notes that the new B117 variant, which is dominant in Europe and resurgent in the U.S., is 50 percent more communicable and 30 percent more lethal.
